subject: 🧠 Lack of Psychological Safety: Why Inclusion Can’t Survive Without It
body:
Continue reading to learn how to create a psychologically safe environment for all employees. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Tamara!
 
🛑
 Picture this: 
You're leading a team meeting.
An employee has a brilliant idea, but they hesitate. 
"What if I am dismissed? What if I get labeled "difficult"?
So, they stay silent. Again. Now imagine this happening to employees across your organization, every single day. 
 
🤔
 The Experience: 
For many employees, especially those from underrepresented backgrounds, this is a daily reality.
They 
hold back
, they 
mask their identity
, they 
self-censor
, not because they don’t care…but because the environment has taught them it’s not safe to show up fully. 
Leaders like you are doing the work—you’re committed to DEI, you’ve launched initiatives, and built task forces. But without psychological safety, none of it sticks. 
 
⚠️
 The Problem: 
When your team doesn’t feel safe to speak up, challenge the status quo, or express themselves authentically, your organization suffers: 
Innovation stalls. 
Engagement declines. 
Diverse talent quietly leaves. 
Inclusion becomes performative. 
Lack of psychological safety 
erodes trust
, and with it, your DEI efforts lose their power. You’re left managing programs that check boxes but don’t change hearts.
 
💡
 The Future You’re Waiting For: 
Now, picture this instead: 
A culture where every employee—regardless of role, identity, or background—feels not just seen but 
safe
.
Where a Black employee challenges a policy without fear.
Where a trans team member can correct misgendering confidently.
Where junior staff raise bold ideas without worrying they’ll be shut down. 
That’s when DEI becomes more than a program—it becomes 
a lived experience
. 
And it starts with psychological safety. 
 
🎤
 What’s Next: 
In a few days, I’ll be sending you 
Part 2
, packed with specific, actionable strategies to build psychological safety in your workplace. 
Because inclusion can’t survive without it—and your people can’t thrive without it. 
👉
 Watch your inbox for the next email. It’s one you don’t want to miss. 
 
 
Bye for now, 
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, Founder and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.
At 
Mastering Cultural Differences LLC,
 we are committed to helping organizations build inclusive, culturally competent workplaces where every individual feels valued and respected. Through highly customized programs, we equip teams with knowledge and skills to help them connect and collaborate more effectively across differences. subject: 👗 🥻 👳🏻 Redefining professionalism with respect
body:
Continue reading to learn how to create a culturally responsive dress code for your organization. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Tamara!
 
👋
 
Welcome Back
Earlier this week, we explored how traditional dress codes may be unintentionally excluding employees from expressing their cultural identities—and how that quiet exclusion can erode belonging. 
 
Now let’s talk about what you 
can
 do, as a forward-thinking leader, to challenge outdated norms and create a more inclusive environment that works for everyone. 
 
🧭
 
Strategy 1: Reevaluate the Origins of Your Current Dress Code
Ask yourself and your leadership team: 
When was this policy created—and who was it designed for?
Often, dress codes are inherited from decades-old corporate standards that centered a narrow view of professionalism. This is your opportunity to reassess whether your current policy truly reflects your workforce 
today
.
 
📣
 
Strategy 2: Involve Employees in the Conversation
Inclusion starts with listening. Create safe spaces for employees to share feedback about how current dress code policies affect them.
Consider launching a brief survey or hosting listening sessions. By involving your teams in policy evolution, you build trust, increase buy-in, and gain insights into diverse dress norms that you may not have considered.
 
 
📄
 
Strategy 3: Define Professionalism with Cultural Flexibility
Yes, professionalism matters—but it doesn’t have to be rigid or monocultural. The key is to develop clear, inclusive dress code guidelines that accommodate religious or cultural attire (e.g., hijabs, turbans, saris, dashikis, etc.) while maintaining appropriateness for the role.
Clarity helps prevent subjective interpretations and ensures consistency across departments.
 
🤝
 
Strategy 4: Allow for Individual Accommodation
Make it known that your organization supports respectful accommodations when needed.
For example: Religious head coverings, gender-affirming attire, or cultural garments worn for traditional observance should be welcomed—not penalized. This reinforces a message of respect and dignity for all employees.
 
Strategy 5: Lead by Example with Cultural Competence Training
Ensure that leaders and managers are equipped with the tools to understand, appreciate, and support cultural differences—including attire. 
 A culturally competent leader sets the tone for inclusion from the top down.  
 
Dress codes may seem small—but they speak volumes. When employees no longer have to choose between authenticity and acceptance, they show up more engaged, more confident, and more committed to your mission. 
By implementing culturally inclusive policies, you send a powerful message: 
👥
 
Everyone belongs here—exactly as they are.
 
  
📞
 
Let’s Build This Together
If you’re ready to take the next step to create a truly inclusive organization, I’d love to support you. 
Schedule a complimentary strategy call
 with me today, and let’s explore how 
Mastering Cultural Differences
 can help you lead systemic, lasting change.
 
📅
 
Book Your Free Call Now
 
 
 
Together, we’ll create a workplace where every identity is seen—and every voice is heard. 
Bye for now, 
Luiza
___________________________________

subject: 👗 👔 Culturally Inclusive Dress Codes: Challenging the Conventional Notion of “Professional Image”
body:
Continue reading to learn how to create a culturally inclusive dress code for your organization. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Tamara!
 
Could your dress code be silently excluding people? 
 
🛑
 
Picture this
Imagine walking into your office and realizing that the very policies meant to reflect professionalism are making some of your most talented employees feel like outsiders. They hesitate at the closet each morning, wondering: 
“Will what I wear today be considered ‘professional’ enough—or too different to be accepted?”
 
Your organization may pride itself on being inclusive—but if the dress code only reflects one cultural norm, it may be unintentionally silencing others. 
 
🥻
 
The Experience
For an Indian woman, a sari is not just an attire—it’s heritage. For a Muslim man, wearing a thobe is a symbol of faith and identity. Yet, in many workplaces, these expressions of culture are quietly discouraged in favor of Western-style suits and skirts. 
Employees begin to self-censor. They conform—not because they want to—but because they feel they have to. And in doing so, they leave a part of themselves at the door. 
 
⚠️
 
The Problem
When your dress code reinforces a narrow idea of what “professional” looks like, it doesn’t just limit wardrobe choices—it limits belonging. 
This seemingly minor policy issue becomes a major roadblock to inclusion. Employees feel unseen, undervalued, and disconnected. For team leaders, it becomes a source of friction, pushback, and quiet disengagement that erodes culture from within. 
 
💡
 
The Future You’re Waiting For
Now picture this: Your employees walk through the door proud of who they are—and how they show up. Their attire reflects their culture, their values, and their full selves. 
Your dress code doesn’t dilute professionalism—it expands it. And your organization becomes known not just for hiring diverse talent, but for keeping it. 
This is the kind of culture where 
everyone feels like they truly belong
. A culture that thrives on authenticity—not uniformity. 
 
🎤
 
What’s Next
In Part 2 of this series, coming later this week, I’ll share 
practical, actionable strategies
 to help you evolve your dress code policies in ways that are inclusive, respectful, and still aligned with your organization’s standards. 
Let’s move beyond outdated norms and create policies that actually reflect the diverse people who make your workplace great. 
 
👉
 Stay tuned—change is on the way.
 
Bye for now, 
 
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, Founder and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.
At 
Mastering Cultural Differences LLC,
 we are committed to helping organizations build inclusive, culturally competent workplaces where every individual feels valued and respected. Through highly customized programs, we equip teams with knowledge and skills to help them connect and collaborate more effectively across differences. subject: Neurodiversity Celebration Week; World Hearing Day; and more!
body:
In this action-packed edition, you'll find:
 
 
Dear colleagues,
In this action-packed edition, you'll find:
1
. Neurodiversity Celebration Week, 
an interview with 
Included 
consultant, Lydia Collins, about her journey as a neurodivergent person.
2. 
World Hearing Day
 was on March 3rd. Learn more about our Director of Operations, Vikki Barron, and her own personal hearing loss journey including the link between hearing loss and long-term brain health.
3. An invitation to our upcoming events: 
 
Breaking Barriers: Beyond the Hashtags, Beyond IWD
Using Data in EDI: Driving Evidence-Based Inclusion Strategies
From Policy to Progress: How EU Directives Can Drive Culture Change 
(Please note new date/time below!)
4. The audio book of our most recent publication ‘
The Key to Inclusion
’ is out now! Rob Adediran shares his key takeaways from the first chapter. There is also a chance of winning a free audio book code!
Click on the links below to dive deeper into each topic.
 
As always, we’re here for any questions or additional information you may need.
 
Warm regards,
Your 
Included
 Team 
  
Neurodiversity Celebration Week
Learn more about 
Included 
consultant Lydia Collins and her journey as a neurodivergent person.
"
I realised I’m just using a different ‘operating system’ to my neurotypical peers. We don’t always think the same way, and that’s great. Knowing this helps me feel more able to be my true self, bringing my unique perspective, experience, and skills to my work.
"
  
Read Now
 
Embracing Hearing Aids: A Game-Changer for Long-Term Health
For World Hearing Day (3rd March), our Director of Operations, Vikki, shared her journey with hearing loss – and why she’s now a proud hearing aid wearer.
"I first noticed my hearing loss in my 30s while working in noisy TV production offices. I’d miss parts of conversations unless I was face-to-face and focused on whomever was speaking. At first, I reluctantly tried hearing aids, but I felt way too young to need them. I convinced myself I could manage without them.
Fast forward a few years, and working remotely at Included allowed me to control my sound environment, making hearing aids feel unnecessary. I thought I had it all figured out...
"
  
Continue reading...
 
Breaking Barriers: Beyond the Hashtags, Beyond IWD
The conversation on equity and inclusion cannot be confined to a single day. As Women’s History Month comes to a close, join us for a powerful and thought-provoking session with keynote speaker 
Dimple Agarwal
, a leader and advocate for equity in the workplace.
In this session, Dimple will bring to life the realities of workplace culture and discrimination, the barriers to real inclusion, and the urgent need for systemic change. Drawing from her extensive experience, both in the corporate world and supporting individuals facing discrimination, she will challenge the myths of corporate progress and provide tangible actions to accelerate action and drive meaningful change. 
  
Sign-up here
 
Using Data in EDI: Driving Evidence-Based Inclusion Strategies
In today’s data-driven world, harnessing the right insights is key to building inclusive workplaces. But how can organisations effectively use data to inform and enhance their EDI strategies?
In this session, discover how to leverage data for meaningful change by:
•    Identifying key metrics that reflect inclusion and equity in your organisation
•    Using data to measure, monitor, and improve EDI initiatives
•    Embedding evidence-based strategies into everyday practices
•    Equipping leaders with insights to drive accountability and inclusive growth
  
Sign-up here
 
Note new time and date: 07 May 2025, 13:00-1400 GMT:
From Policy to Progress: How EU Directives Can Drive Culture Change
With the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) now in effect and the Gender Representation Directive set to go live next year, companies with an EU presence face an evolving regulatory landscape that extends far beyond pay equity and transparency.
At the same time, organisations in the UK are finalising their gender pay gap submissions, with encouragement to extend to disability and ethnicity pay gap reporting too. Whilst the US may push back on EDI, the rest of the world pushes forward,
Join us for another insightful webinar where, this time, we’ll explore how these EU directives are reshaping workplace expectations and what they mean for your organisation.
  
Sign-up here
 
The Key to Inclusion Audiobook
 
We are delighted to share that our book, 
The Key to Inclusion
, is now available in audio format. This book, written in 2022, is a practical guide to Diversity, Equity and Belonging for You, Your Team and Your Organisation. Recognising the importance of diversity, belonging and equity is not enough and this book has the practical guidance needed to think differently and make true inclusion a reality.
To mark this exciting moment, we are offering you the chance of winning a free audio book code. Please visit the below link for further information. Good Luck!
 
Find out more
 
Find out more about 
Included
’s approach to diversity 
here
 and take a look at our 
Impact Report
. 
Please 
get in touch
 with us anytime to have a conversation about making your organisation more diverse and more inclusive.  We look forward to hearing from you. 
From all of us at 
Included

Hello Tamara!
 
📩
 
Following up on our last email…
We explored how 
power distance
—the level of hierarchy expected in the workplace—can impact team dynamics. When employees hesitate to speak up or leaders unknowingly reinforce hierarchy, inclusion suffers. 
But the good news? 
You can bridge this gap with the right strategies.
 
Here’s how to 
ensure power distance doesn’t hold your team dynamics back.
 
 
🗣️
 
1. Adapt Your Leadership Style
A one-size-fits-all approach won’t work if you’re managing a team with different cultural expectations. In 
high power-distance
 cultures, provide clear structure and guidance while gradually encouraging participation. In 
low power-distance
 cultures, foster open dialogue and collaborative decision-making. 
 
🤝
 
2. Set Clear Expectations Around Participation
Make it known that 
every voice matters.
 Some employees may be used to top-down decision-making, so explicitly state: 
“
Your input is valued, and we encourage different perspectives. As part of our culture, we expect everyone to contribute ideas in meetings.” 
Small shifts in messaging 
signal that participation is not just welcome but expected.
 
 
📊
 
3. Use Different Feedback Channels
For employees hesitant to challenge authority publicly, 
create alternative ways to share feedback 
such as anonymous surveys, private feedback channels, or one-on-one check-ins with leadership. This removes social pressure and 
gives all employees a way to be heard.
 
 
🌟
 
4. Coach Leaders to Be Cultural Translators
Managers play a critical role in bridging power distance. Train them to:
🔹
 Recognize when hierarchy is shaping team dynamics
🔹
 Invite participation in ways that align with cultural norms
🔹
 Create psychologically safe spaces where speaking up isn’t seen as a risk 
 
🚀
 
5. Leverage Mentorship & Sponsorship
Employees from high power-distance cultures may wait for permission to advance. 
Pair them with mentors who encourage self-advocacy and leadership development. 
Sponsorship programs can also help high-potential employees 
gain visibility
 and confidence in contributing. 
 
🎯
 
What’s Next? Let’s Put These Strategies into Action!
Understanding power distance is just the first step—applying it effectively is where the real transformation happens. 
Let’s chat! 
Schedule a complimentary call with me
 to discuss how you can implement these strategies and build a more inclusive, globally aware workplace. 
📅
 
Schedule Your Call Here
 
 
Here’s to creating workplaces where cultural differences matter! 
Bye for now, 
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, Founder and CEO (she/her/hers)

body:
Continue reading to learn how to protect foreign workers from discrimination and create and inclusive organization. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Dear Tamara,
 
❗
 
“I don’t want you in here… Send someone American.”
 
❗
 
Imagine being a skilled, compassionate caregiver—only to be rejected because of your nationality.  
Unfortunately, this happens far too often in healthcare and senior care facilities. 
📢
 In the latest DEI+ Newsletter, 
“
I Want Someone American:” Protecting Foreign Workers from Discrimination
,
 I reveal how bias—whether subtle or explicit—affects workers, damages organizational culture, and violates civil rights. More importantly, I provide actionable strategies to build truly inclusive workplaces where 
every employee feels valued.
 
💡
 And to help you take the next step, I’m also offering 
Bridging Cultures with Care: Fun & Inclusive Activities for Nursing Homes & Assisted Living Facilities
—a resource filled with engaging activities like 
Cultural Bingo, storytelling, and guided conversations 
to foster connection and break down biases. 
 
🔗
 
Read the full article & request your free activities here!
 
📖👇
 
 
 
 Let’s create bias-free work environments 
💪
 
Bye for now!
Luiza

subject: 📢 Are Hidden Hierarchies Holding Your Inclusion Efforts Back?
body:
Continue reading for...... ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Tamara!
 
🛑
 
Picture this:
You’ve launched a new initiative, encouraging employees to share their ideas and concerns. Your goal? An inclusive workplace where everyone feels heard. 
Yet, in some global teams, silence fills the room. Junior employees hesitate to speak in meetings. Some leaders make decisions with little input from their teams. And despite your efforts, true inclusivity feels out of reach. 
 
🤔
 
The Experience:
Imagine a new hire from a hierarchical culture—where questioning leadership is seen as disrespectful. When asked for feedback, they stay quiet, unsure if speaking up is truly welcome. Meanwhile, their manager—accustomed to top-down leadership—assumes silence means agreement. 
The result? 
Missed perspectives, disengaged employees, and stalled progress on your goals.
 
 
⚠️
 
The Problem:
Global teams bring diverse perspectives, but power distance—the level of hierarchy people expect in the workplace—shapes how employees engage. In 
high power-distance cultures
, hierarchy is respected, and decisions flow from the top. In 
low power-distance cultures
, employees expect open dialogue and shared decision-making. 
When these cultural expectations clash:
❌
 Employees from hierarchical cultures hesitate to challenge authority.
❌
 Leaders from egalitarian cultures struggle to engage hierarchical teams.
❌
 Critical workplace discussions remain one-sided, limiting real change. 
 
💡
 
The Future You’re Waiting For:
Now, imagine an organization where:
✅
 Every employee—regardless of background—feels empowered to contribute.
✅
 Leaders recognize and adapt to different cultural expectations.
✅
 Inclusion initiatives succeed because engagement isn’t dictated by hierarchy. 
 
🎤
 
What’s Next?
In my next email, I’ll share 
specific strategies
 to navigate power distance effectively—so you can foster a truly inclusive workplace without cultural misalignment holding you back. Stay tuned! 
 
Bye for now, 
Luiza
___________________________________

subject: 🔓 Unlocking Leadership Potential: Breaking the “Positive” Stereotype Barrier
body:
Continue reading to learn more about the impact of stereotypes in the workplace. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Tamara!
 
👋
 
Remember Mei from my last email?
 The high-performing employee whose career stalled because she was seen as a great worker—but not a leader? 
She’s not alone.  
When positive stereotypes limit career growth, organizations lose out on diverse leadership, innovation, and employee engagement.
 
But here’s the good news: 
You have the power to change this.
  
Here are 
five actionable strategies
 to dismantle the hidden barriers of “positive” stereotypes in your workplace:
 
1️⃣ 
Redefine Leadership Beyond the Traditional Mold
Too often, leadership is defined by outdated, Western-centric traits—assertiveness, outspokenness, and charisma. 
Expand your definition
 to value diverse leadership styles like collaboration, cultural intelligence, and thoughtful decision-making.  
Ask yourself:
 Are my promotion criteria inclusive of different leadership approaches? 
 
2️⃣ 
Audit Performance Reviews for Bias
Unconscious bias creeps into performance evaluations. Asian employees, for example, may be praised for technical skills but overlooked for strategic thinking or leadership potential. 
Solution:
 Conduct bias audits in your review and promotion processes. Ensure that growth opportunities aren’t based on assumptions but on demonstrated impact and potential. 
 
3️⃣ 
Create Sponsorship, Not Just Mentorship
Mentorship is great, but sponsorship is a game-changer. Sponsors actively 
advocate
 for employees, recommending them for high-visibility projects and leadership roles. 
Action Step:
 Pair underrepresented employees with senior leaders who can advocate for their growth—not just offer advice. 
 
4️⃣ 
Foster a Culture Where All Voices Are Heard
Employees who don’t fit the traditional leadership mold may hesitate to speak up in meetings—especially if they’ve been conditioned to stay in the background. 
Solution:
 
Encourage psychological safety in meetings. Actively invite different perspectives, and ensure that contributions are valued—not dismissed or overlooked. 
 
5️⃣ 
Offer Cultural Competence Training
The best way to tackle unconscious bias? 
Awareness and education.
 Provide ongoing training that helps managers and employees recognize and challenge stereotypes in real time. 
 
 
🎯
 
Need a customized approach? Let’s talk.
Breaking free from “positive” stereotypes isn’t just about fairness—it’s about unlocking the full potential of your workforce. Let’s discuss how you can implement these strategies in your organization.  
Schedule a complimentary call with me today, and let’s start building a truly inclusive leadership pipeline.
 
 
 
📅
 
Book Your Complimentary Call Now
 
 
 
Bye for now, 
Luiza

subject: 🚨 The Hidden Cost of “Positive” Stereotypes in the Workplace
body:
Continue reading to learn more about the impact of stereotypes in the workplace. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Tamara!
 
🛑
 
Picture this:
Imagine a high-performing employee on your team—let’s call her Mei. Mei is incredibly detail-oriented, excellent with numbers, and rarely speaks up in meetings. Leadership views her as a “perfect team player” because she never challenges decisions or takes risks. She’s frequently praised for being diligent, but when it comes to promotions, Mei is passed over. The assumption? She’s not “leadership material.” 
 
🤔
 
The Experience:
For many professionals—especially those from underrepresented backgrounds—so-called 
“positive” stereotypes
 create invisible barriers. For example, Asian Americans are seen as technically gifted but lacking leadership presence. Black women are assumed to be strong and resilient, but not “warm” enough for executive roles. Women in general are praised for being collaborative but criticized when they assert authority. 
These stereotypes may seem complimentary, but they 
box employees in
, limiting opportunities and stalling careers. 
 
⚠️
 
The Problem:
When organizations unknowingly reinforce these biases, they:
🚧
 Fail to recognize diverse leadership styles, narrowing their talent pipeline.
🚧
 Create disengagement as employees feel unseen or undervalued.
🚧
 Lose out on innovation and diverse perspectives that drive business success. 
And when employees feel trapped by stereotypes, inclusion remains an illusion.
 
 
💡
 
The Future You’re Waiting For:
Now, imagine a workplace where every employee—regardless of race, gender, or background—is seen for their 
unique strengths and leadership potential.
 A workplace where diverse perspectives thrive, and opportunities are based on 
capabilities, not assumptions.
 
That kind of inclusive culture isn’t just possible—it’s necessary for long-term success. 
 
🎤
 
What’s Next:
In my next email, I’ll share 
specific strategies
 to break free from these “positive” stereotypes and foster a truly inclusive workplace. Watch your inbox for actionable steps to drive real change. 
 
 
Bye for now, 
Luiza

subject: More “Masculine Energy?” No thanks…Bring on the Lionesses.
body:
“You know, Mom, you’re like lionesses!”
 
 
 
My daughter and I were walking to school the other morning. Along the way, I exchanged greetings with several female neighbors. We exchanged brief words of encouragement, checked in on how things were going with family members and jobs, offered assistance with kids and meals.  
My daughter said, “You know, Mom, you’re like lionesses!” 
Now, for some context, my kid and I watch a lot of wildlife documentaries. Lions often represent the pinnacle of masculine strength, with the male lion being lauded as the “King of the Beasts.” But that moniker doesn’t give much credit to who’s really running the pride.
Unlike most animal species, lion prides are matriarchal. The females create a centralized, stable system around which the pride functions. Lionesses are deeply social and collaborative. They not only care for the cubs, they also do the majority of the hunting and are fierce defenders, taking on much larger predators to protect their pride. 
When leaders like Mark Zuckerberg complain that the corporate world has become 
“culturally neutered” and call for more  “masculine energy” in the workplace
, what they mean is a work culture that rewards behaviors that go 
against
 the cooperative mentality that makes a pride thrive - they're talking about aggressive, winner-take-all, competitive behaviors that drive isolation, not collaboration.
This is problematic for multiple reasons. 
It overlooks the fact that 
masculinity contest work cultures are counterproductive
, and not only that, 
women and men alike
 don’t actually like working in them.  Studies have shown that constructive organizational cultures are both humanistic and achievement-oriented. They reward healthy competition and constructive conflict as well as empathy, compassion, and collaboration. 
 
It contributes to the rising wave of toxic masculinity, which is not only backwards but dangerous. Global studies are finding that  
women are increasingly afraid of men
, and with good reason. Cases of assault, stalking, and violence against women and members of the trans community have increased dramatically in the last few years. In the US, there was a 
4600 percent increase in misogynistic speech in December 2024 following the November election
. For example, terms like, "Your body, my choice" and "Get back in the kitchen" increased exponentially on the social media platform X. 
 
It further diminishes women’s participation in what have been traditionally male-dominated industries and jobs, including science, technology, math, and engineering (STEM), finance, venture capital, law enforcement, and active combat. In all of these industries, women can and do play critical roles and are 
found to be equal in competence to their male counterparts
, and in some cases provide unique values because of their identity experiences. 
Women’s History Month is a opportunity to celebrate the great many accomplishments of women throughout the generations. Yet, it is also a call to action for all of us, 
including men
, to contribute to cultures that promote more collaboration and compassion alongside healthy competition. Ditch the bro culture, chainsaw wielding, “Go back to the kitchen” messages. They ultimately don’t serve anyone, not even the bros with the chainsaws. 
 
Maria Morukian
Founder and Chief Executive Officer
MSM Global Consulting
MSM GLOBAL UPDATES
 
This past month, Maria Morukian shared two insightful articles on LinkedIn that explore critical conversations shaping the future of diversity, equity, and inclusion. As organizations navigate evolving legal landscapes and push back against the false narratives surrounding merit and inclusion, these pieces from Harvard Business Review offer timely perspectives. Below, we summarize key takeaways from each article and why they matter for leaders committed to DEI as a strategic priority:
How to Assess the New Legal Risks of Your DEI Policies
As legal challenges to DEI policies become more prevalent, organizations must proactively assess risk while staying true to their commitment to equity. This HBR article provides a strategic framework for leaders to evaluate their DEI initiatives in light of evolving regulations. It outlines key legal considerations, including affirmative action rollbacks, new compliance expectations, and the importance of transparency in decision-making. Rather than retreating from DEI efforts, businesses are encouraged to refine their strategies which will ensure they align with both legal and ethical imperatives. The article underscores the need for ongoing education, legal consultation, and thoughtful adaptation to maintain inclusive workplaces without compromising compliance.
The False Dichotomy of Merit and Inclusion
One of the most persistent myths in DEI conversations is the idea that merit and inclusion are opposing forces. This article challenges that false dichotomy, arguing that diversity actually enhances merit by broadening the pool of talent and perspectives within an organization. The piece critiques outdated views of meritocracy, which often fail to account for systemic barriers that limit opportunity. By redefining merit to include diverse experiences and capabilities, businesses can cultivate stronger, more innovative teams. The takeaway? Inclusion isn’t, and has never been, about lowering standards. 
It’s about recognizing excellence in all its forms from diverse backgrounds and institutions.
 
Culture Stew
Last year we produced this episode, and  thought it was worth a reheat, especially considering the increasing challenges public educators face in supporting the needs of diverse students. Culturally fluent education is increasingly crucial to the future success of our children. In this episode of Culture Stew, Maria met with Dr. Ayanna F. Brown to explore the evolving landscape of equity in education. From systemic challenges to actionable strategies, Dr. Brown shares her insights on fostering meaningful change in schools and communities. Whether you're an educator, leader, or advocate, this conversation sheds light on the work needed to create inclusive learning environments that truly serve all students.

How Americans See Men and Masculinity | Pew Research Center
A recent Pew Research Center study explored how Americans perceive the roles and expectations of men today. The findings highlight generational and ideological divides in attitudes toward traditional masculinity, emotional expression, and societal pressures on men. While many acknowledge the challenges men face, including mental health struggles and rigid gender norms, there is also growing support for redefining masculinity in ways that embrace vulnerability, caregiving, and emotional intelligence. This report provides valuable insight into how these shifting perspectives influence workplaces, relationships, and broader social dynamics.
Women leaders make work better. Here’s the science behind how to promote them.
Research from the American Psychological Association reveals that female leaders are not only breaking barriers but also transforming workplace cultures for the better. The study highlights how organizations with women in leadership roles tend to foster more inclusive, supportive, and equitable environments—benefiting employees across all demographics. Women leaders are more likely to implement policies that prioritize well-being, mentorship, and collaboration, ultimately driving higher engagement and performance. The article underscores the importance of diversifying leadership teams and challenging outdated biases about gender and leadership effectiveness.

CONTENT FOR YOUR DOWN TIME
Here are some recommended articles and books for your down time.
 
Black Panther Woman
: The Political and Spiritual Life of 
Ericka Huggins
 (Black Power)
By 
 
Mary Frances Phillips
Ericka Huggins’ Black Panther Woman is a testament to the resilience, leadership, and revolutionary spirit of Black women in the fight for justice. As a key figure in the Black Panther Party, Huggins not only challenged racial and social oppression but also redefined the role of Black women in activism, balancing political resistance with spiritual resilience. Her story highlights the often-overlooked contributions of Black women in shaping movements, fostering community, and leading with both strength and compassion. In a world that seeks to silence them, Huggins’ life is a powerful reminder that Black women are, and always have been, at the forefront of change.
The Witch Boy
By 
Molly Knox Ostertag 
Molly Knox Ostertag’s The Witch Boy is a powerful tale of identity and self-discovery that can resonate deeply with transgender and gender-nonconforming readers. The main character, Aster, struggles against rigid gender roles, where boys must be shapeshifters and girls are witches, mirrors the experience of those who defy societal expectations to embrace their true selves. His journey is a testament to the courage it takes to live authentically, showing young readers that identity is personal, not prescribed. By challenging norms with warmth and magic,
The Witch Boy affirms that being yourself is not only possible but necessary.

Hello Tamara!
 
🔄
 
Remember This?
Earlier this week, I shared how many organizations unknowingly 
overlook neurodivergent employees
 (ADHD, autism, dyslexia, etc.).  
Traditional workplaces often 
expect one way of thinking and working
—leading to disengagement, burnout, and untapped potential. 
But it doesn’t have to be this way.  
Neurodivergent employees aren’t liabilities—they are untapped powerhouses of creativity, innovation, and problem-solving.
The key? 
Creating an environment that works for them, not against them.
 
 
Here’s how to start.
 
👇
 
 
🧠
 
1. Rethink “Productivity”
Not everyone thrives in the 
9-to-5, desk-bound
 work model. Some employees do their best thinking in 
short bursts
. Others need 
flexible schedules
 to align with their cognitive rhythms. 
✅
 
Strategy:
 Offer flexible work options—remote work, varied work hours, and project-based deadlines instead of rigid time blocks. 
 
💬
 
2. Communication Styles Matter
Neurodivergent employees may process verbal, written, or visual communication 
differently
. One person might struggle with 
long, detailed emails
, while another might find 
face-to-face conversations overwhelming
. 
✅
 
Strategy:
 Ask employees 
how they prefer to receive and share information.
 Use multiple formats—written summaries, bullet points, voice notes, or even quick check-ins—to support diverse communication needs. 
 
🏢
 
3. Create Sensory-Friendly Workspaces
Open offices, 
harsh lighting
, and constant noise can be 
overstimulating
 for neurodivergent employees. These distractions can 
tank productivity
 and make it hard to focus. 
✅
 
Strategy:
 Offer 
quiet workspaces, noise-canceling headphones, adjustable lighting, or remote work options
 to create ways for employees to do their best work. 
 
🛠️
 
4. Adjust Expectations Around Meetings
Traditional meetings can be draining for neurodivergent employees—especially those who need 
more processing time
 or struggle with 
verbal brainstorming on the spot
. 
✅
 
Strategy:
🔹
 
Provide agendas in advance
 so employees can prepare.
🔹
 Allow for 
written contributions
 for those who think better through text.
🔹
 Consider 
shorter, structured meetings
 to avoid unnecessary cognitive overload. 
 
🎯
 
5. Focus on Strengths, Not Deficits
Instead of expecting neurodivergent employees to 
fit into existing structures
, shape their roles around 
what they do best.
 
✅
 
Strategy:
 Identify and 
leverage their unique skills
—whether it’s pattern recognition, deep focus, problem-solving, or creativity—and align them with tasks that amplify those strengths. 
 
🎤
 
What’s Next? 
These changes 
don’t require a complete workplace overhaul
—just 
small, intentional shifts
 that can unlock 
game-changing potential
 in your team. 
 
 
🚀
 
Ready to Build a More Inclusive Workplace?
Schedule a complimentary call with me, and let’s craft a strategy for a more inclusive, engaged workforce.
📅
 
Book Your Strategy Session Now
 
 
 
Here’s to creating workplaces where all individuals can be their best!
Bye for now, 
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, President and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.
At

 we are committed to helping organizations build inclusive, culturally competent workplaces where every individual feels valued and respected. subject: Canceled: Int'l Womens Day Panel - Dress Rehearsal
body:
Hi everyone, 
 
I took a peak at your calendars and saw this time slot open for everyone to have a dress rehearsal for our panel discussion on March 19

subject: 🧠 Unlocking Potential: Are You Overlooking Neurodivergent Talent?
body:
Continue reading to learn how you can support your neurodivergent talent. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Tamara!
 
🛑
 
Picture This:
You’re in a leadership meeting discussing why some employees struggle with collaboration, time management, or traditional performance expectations. One team member, brilliant in problem-solving, often misses deadlines. Another employee, incredibly detail-oriented, gets overwhelmed in brainstorming sessions. Despite their unique strengths, they seem to be “underperforming.” 
But what if the real issue isn’t 
their performance
—but how your workplace accommodates 
different ways of thinking
? 
 
🤔
 
The Experience:
Imagine being an employee with ADHD, expected to work in an open office full of distractions. Or an autistic professional asked to "just speak up more" in meetings when they process information differently. A dyslexic team member might have groundbreaking ideas but struggles with written communication. 
Instead of feeling 
supported
, these employees often believe they have to 
mask their differences
—which leads to stress, burnout, and disengagement. 
 
⚠️
 
The Problem:
Neurodivergent employees are leaving—or never applying—because workplaces aren’t built for them. In fact, many leaders still believe “one-size-fits-all” productivity models work. They don’t. 
Your company could be losing out on 
innovation, creative problem-solving, and unique perspectives
 by not embracing neurodiversity. 
When neurodivergent employees 
don’t feel valued, they disengage.
 And disengagement isn’t just an HR issue—it’s a 
business risk
. Low retention, high turnover costs, and a lack of truly diverse thinking hold companies back from real progress. 
 
💡
 
The Future You’re Waiting For:
Imagine a workplace where:
✅
 
Meetings accommodate different communication styles.
✅
 
Workspaces are designed to minimize distractions for focused thinking.
✅
 
Employees are valued for their strengths—not penalized for differences.
 
When neurodivergent employees feel 
empowered, not excluded
, they 
thrive
—bringing 
creativity, innovation, and fresh perspectives
 that drive business success. 
 
🎤
 
What’s Next:
In my next email, I’ll share 
specific, actionable strategies
 to make your workplace 
more inclusive for neurodivergent talent
—without major overhauls or unrealistic expectations. 
📩
 
Stay tuned for Part 2!
 It’s time to stop overlooking 
neurodivergent brilliance
 and start unlocking 
true potential
 in your organization. 
  
Bye for now, 
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, President and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.
At 
Mastering Cultural Differences LLC,
 we are committed to helping organizations build inclusive, culturally competent workplaces where every individual feels valued and respected. Through highly customized programs, we equip teams with knowledge and skills to help them connect and collaborate more effectively across differences. subject: 4 March: The Temptations of a Modern Marketer
body:
Join our free webinar with Fernando Machado and discover how to avoid the pitfalls of marketing today

View in browser
 
 
 
Working in marketing nowadays can be confusing at best. Between pressure on results from your business and the temptation to try new tricks that offer quick wins (but don’t always deliver) – it’s never been tougher to develop great creative work that drives growth.
 
But on 4 March, 
Fernando Machado

. He’ll reveal the state of play in the industry today and share his expertise on what to take and what to leave as you shape your career tomorrow – answering these key questions:
 
REGISTER FOR THE WEBINAR
 
 
The LIONS gMBA

. The LIONS gMBA shows you how to turn creativity into a competitive advantage for your career – in a live, 12-week learning journey where you’ll hear from marketing experts who’ve helped create the world’s best work – and got the results to prove it.

subject: 📢 Strategies to Bridge Hierarchy & Build Inclusive Global Teams 🌍
body:
Continue reading for strategies to bridge the hierarchy gap in your global team. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Tamara!
Looping back... 
⏪
In my last email, I shared how cultural hierarchies can silence voices in global teams. When power dynamics dictate who speaks and who stays quiet, organizations miss out on diverse perspectives—and that means lost innovation, engagement, and growth. 
The good news is that hierarchy doesn’t have to be a barrier. With intentional strategies, you can create an environment where all employees—regardless of title or background—feel empowered to contribute. Here’s how: 
 
1️⃣ 
Cultivate a Speak-Up Culture 
In many cultures, openly sharing opinions—especially with senior leaders—may not come naturally. Leaders must intentionally create an environment where all voices are encouraged and valued. A simple prompt like, 
"I’d love to hear different perspectives on this,"
 can make a big difference. 
✅
 
Tip:
 Implement structured meeting formats where every participant knows in advance that they will have an equal opportunity to contribute. This approach prevents dominant voices from taking over and ensures a balanced, inclusive discussion where diverse insights can thrive. 
 
2️⃣ 
Train Leaders to Navigate Diverse Communication Styles 
Silence doesn’t always mean agreement—in some cultures, it signifies respect or hesitation. Without this understanding, leaders may misinterpret engagement levels and overlook valuable input. 
✅
 
Tip:
 Equip leaders with the skills to recognize and adapt to diverse communication styles. Culturally competent leaders “read the room,” foster inclusion, and create space for all voices to be heard. 
 
3️⃣ 
Implement Structured Meeting Formats 
Unstructured discussions often amplify the loudest voices, leaving others unheard. By using clear frameworks, you create a more inclusive space where every team member has the opportunity to contribute. 
✅
 
Tip:
 Try the 
“1-2-4-All” technique
 to encourage thoughtful participation at every level:
🔹
 
1 min
 – Reflect individually on the topic.
🔹
 
2 min
 – Discuss ideas with a partner.
🔹
 
4 min
 – Share insights in small groups.
🔹
 
All
 – Present key takeaways to the larger team. 
This method ensures balanced engagement, fosters diverse perspectives, and prevents discussions from being dominated by a few voices. 
 
4️⃣ 
Establish Meaningful Mentorship Programs 
Hierarchical structures can make it difficult for employees—especially those in junior roles—to voice their opinions or concerns. A well-designed mentorship program helps bridge this gap by fostering support, guidance, and confidence-building across all levels. 
✅
 
Tip:
 Create mentorship opportunities that connect culturally diverse team members, encouraging collaboration, shared learning, and mutual support to empower every voice in the organization. 
 
5️⃣ 
Embrace a “Collective Leadership” Approach 
Foster a culture where leadership is shared, and every team member feels empowered to contribute—regardless of title or seniority. 
✅
 
Tip:
 Rotate meeting facilitators to give different team members the opportunity to lead discussions, ensuring diverse perspectives shape decision-making and challenging traditional hierarchical norms. 
 
6️⃣ 
Create Alternative Avenues for Input 
Even in the most inclusive environments, some team members may still feel hesitant to voice their opinions in group settings—whether due to cultural norms, personality differences, or past experiences. Great leaders recognize this and provide multiple ways for employees to contribute. 
✅
 
Tip:
 Encourage one-on-one check-ins where employees can share feedback privately or offer written channels like email or anonymous suggestion forms to gather insights. When leaders actively seek input through different formats, they ensure every voice is valued. 
 
🚀
 
Ready to Build a Culturally Competent Workplace?
  
Let’s create a strategy tailored to your team’s unique challenges and goals.  
📅
 
Schedule a
 
complimentary strategy call with me today!
  
 
Here’s to breaking barriers and creating more efficient, culturally competent teams!
🌍✨
 
Bye for now, 
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, President and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.
At 
Mastering Cultural Differences LLC,
 we are committed to helping organizations build inclusive, culturally competent workplaces where every individual feels valued and respected. subject: Standing our ground - US Black History Month; Leadership and Compliance; and more!
body:
In this action-packed edition, you'll find:
 
 
Dear colleagues,
In this action-packed edition, you'll find:
1.
This Too Shall Pass, 
reflections from our Chair and Founder, Stephen Frost, during these trying times.
2. 
It’s still Black History Month in the US, and it’s still important
, an article exploring how racism manifests in the workplace, and the effects.
3. Highlights from our recent webinar "
Beyond SRA Compliance -– Inclusive Leadership for a Thriving Culture
".
4. An invitation to our upcoming events: 
 
"From Policy to Progress: How EU Directives Can Drive Culture Change"
"
Using Data in EDI: Driving Evidence-Based Inclusion Strategies
"
International Women's Day
 fireside chat
5. An opportunity to join our 
audiobook competition
!
 
Click on the links below to dive deeper into each topic.
 
As always, we’re here for any questions or additional information you may need.
 
Warm regards,
Your 
Included
 Team 
  
This Too Shall Pass
Many colleagues are feeling pretty flat right now. For professionals who have dedicated their lives to combatting injustice and improving people’s well-being, many are understandably scared and weary in equal measure about the events now unfolding in the States. What’s being cooked up in Washington, DC is spilling out around the globe.
Make no mistake, this is bad. For many, it’s the worst possible scenario.
Yet, at this undeniably challenging time, we need to find sustenance for the journey ahead and there are two things which I believe can help us:
 
It’s important that we don’t give in or give up
We need to learn to separate the noise from the signal
  
Continue reading...
 
It’s still Black History Month in the US, and it’s still important
This past weekend, I went to my local grocery store like I do most weekends. As I was walking to my car in the parking lot, I heard someone shout, “Go back home! We don’t want you, and we don’t need you!”
If you’re a person of colour in living in the US, this is likely a familiar experience for you. If you’re Black and living in the US, this is probably something you were taught as a child to expect to hear at some point.
This is the reality of life in America. This is why it’s so important to recognise and celebrate Black History Month, even if the federal government has decided not to anymore. This is an opportunity for organisations, and leaders, to step up.
  
Read now
 
Inclusive Leadership: Driving Performance, Not Just Compliance
At 
Included
, we know that inclusive leadership isnt just a ‘nice to have’ - it’s a business imperative. It strengthens engagement, drives retention, and enables firms to perform at their best. But how do we move beyond compliance-driven inclusion and embed it as a core part of how organisations operate?
We explored this in our recent event with leading law firms, where we were joined by Vicki Godfrey, Head of People & Culture at Kingsley Napley. The discussion focused on how law firms are embedding inclusive leadership, the challenges they face, and the opportunities to use regulation as a catalyst for change.
  
Read our post-session insights
 
From Policy to Progress: How EU Directives Can Drive Culture Change
With the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) now in effect and the Gender Representation Directive set to go live next year, companies with an EU presence face an evolving regulatory landscape that extends far beyond pay equity and transparency.
At the same time, organisations in the UK are finalising their gender pay gap submissions, with encouragement to extend to disability and ethnicity pay gap reporting too. Whilst the US may push back on EDI, the rest of the world pushes forward,
Join us for another insightful webinar where, this time, we’ll explore how these EU directives are reshaping workplace expectations and what they mean for your organisation.
  
Sign-up here
 
Using Data in EDI: Driving Evidence-Based Inclusion Strategies
In today’s data-driven world, harnessing the right insights is key to building inclusive workplaces. But how can law firms effectively use data to inform and enhance their EDI strategies?
In this session, discover how to leverage data for meaningful change by:
•    Identifying key metrics that reflect inclusion and equity in your organisation
•    Using data to measure, monitor, and improve EDI initiatives
•    Embedding evidence-based strategies into everyday practices
•    Equipping leaders with insights to drive accountability and inclusive growth
  
Sign-up here
 
Breaking Barriers: Beyond the Hashtags, Beyond IWD
The conversation on equity and inclusion cannot be confined to a single day. As Women’s History Month comes to a close, join us for a powerful and thought-provoking session with keynote speaker 
Dimple Agarwal
, a leader and advocate for equity in the workplace.
In this session, Dimple will bring to life the realities of workplace culture and discrimination, the barriers to real inclusion, and the urgent need for systemic change. Drawing from her extensive experience, both in the corporate world and supporting individuals facing discrimination, she will challenge the myths of corporate progress and provide tangible actions to accelerate action and drive meaningful change. 
  
Sign-up here
 
The Key to Inclusion Audiobook
 
We are delighted to share that our book, 
The Key to Inclusion
, is soon to be available in audio format. This book, written in 2022, is a practical guide to Diversity, Equity and Belonging for You, Your Team and Your Organisation. Recognising the importance of diversity, belonging and equity is not enough and this book has the practical guidance needed to think differently and make true inclusion a reality.
To mark this exciting moment, we are offering you the chance of winning a free audio book code. Please visit the below link for further information. Good Luck!

Subject:
 Int'l Womens Day Panel - Topics
 
Hi everyone, 
 
I connected with Tamara today about several topics, but we covered the panel discussion as well.   Here is a recap of our conversation:
 
Organize a dress rehearsal – Gaelle sent invite for March 12
th
 @ 3:30pm EST 
I saw! Thank you!
Send Tamara panelist names & titles – Gaelle will send
Preview panel discussion questions from Tamara (6-7 questions) 
Lauren and I will also share some questions tomorrow. I’d really love to get a bit deeper than some of the questions you often hear in Women or BIPOC panels, but obviously without getting CONTROVERSIAL. Two of the panelists, Monica (IT) and Anne-Laure (JLC Brand President) work in heavily male dominated roles. Anne-Laure also has to deal with a male-dominated industry and a mostly male clientele. 
Send email introducing Tamara to panel with her bio & send 6-7 questions and have everyone select 1-3 questions they would like to answer (Sulaiman do you want to send?) 
Yes, I can totally send once we’re aligned. I’d like Donna to review the questions in advance too. 
Based on their selection, we can shape the conversation and determine the questions and order
Tamara to prepare the kick off that will include and not limited to:
What is International Womens Day
Why is it important
Women in leadership roles
Do we want to include info on our ESC certification? Share any internal data – we will typically share that we have reached Gender parity in that 52% of our managers identify as women (globally – would need to get stats for the Americas) 
We’ll have to ask Donna. I know there was some sensitivity around the race/ethnicity certification, but Christophe did mention it at the June Town Hall, so I don’t see how this would be different. Maybe if we don’t make it the focus, but just mention it as an achievement?
Tamara will be in OT for the panel discussion – so we can book a conference room for her to take the call – we can join there as well.  Gaelle booked BESPOKE but I am trying to find a room with a window instead – stay tuned
 
@Tamara Thorpe
 – If you can send us a hi-res photo and your bio, that would be great!   
 
Does anyone have anything they want to add/ comments/ input?  Please share 
😊
 
Thank you!
 
Gaelle

View this email in your browser
Upcoming Webinar: March 19th
REGISTER TODAY
Every organization has faced unstable periods or change, but what makes an organization last is ensuring that decisions during these times are not made out of fear. Unpredictability in external factors and events can influence our organizations and lives in ways we could never imagine sometimes (i.e. covid, changes in government, policy shifts, natural disasters, etc.).
These tools will not only help build resilience amongst the leadership but every employee. Even if you believe that you as a leader and your organization are in a stable place, it never hurts to reevaluate how you are connecting with your team. 
There are three areas of influence that team leaders can work within to reduce overwhelm, confusion, and burnout within their teams and organizations and lead with clarity and confidence. Learn more from our latest

subject: 📢 Navigating Hierarchy in Global Organizations 🌍
body:
Continue reading to understand how hierarchical differences impact your global team. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Tamara!
 
💡
 Is Hierarchy Silencing Voices in Your Global Team? 
🌍✨
 
 
🛑
 Picture this:
You’re in a high-stakes meeting with a team spanning multiple countries. As ideas are exchanged, a junior employee from Japan remains silent, while a senior manager from the U.S. dominates the discussion. Later, you learn that the junior employee had a brilliant insight but didn’t feel comfortable speaking up due to cultural norms around hierarchy.
 
🤔
 The Experience:
For many leaders managing global teams, hierarchy can be a silent barrier to true inclusion. In some cultures, freely speaking in front of senior leaders is seen as disrespectful, while in others, open debate is expected. The result? Employees hold back, innovation stalls and diverse perspectives never reach the table. 
 
⚠️ 
The Problem:
When hierarchical structures clash across cultures, it creates:
❌
 A lack of psychological safety, where employees hesitate to share ideas.
❌
 Power imbalances that reinforce exclusion rather than inclusion.
❌
 Decision-making that leans toward dominant voices, leaving diverse insights unheard. 
Organizations seeking diverse team input often underestimate the influence of cultural hierarchies on participation, unintentionally sidelining valuable perspectives. 
 
💡
 The Future You’re Waiting For:
Imagine a workplace where:
✅
 Employees, regardless of title or background, feel empowered to contribute.
✅
 Teams leverage cultural differences as strengths, rather than obstacles.
✅
 Leadership actively fosters an inclusive environment that balances hierarchy with collaboration. 
This future isn’t just possible—it’s essential for thriving in today’s global workforce. 
 
🎤
  What’s Next:
In the next email, I’ll share specific strategies to bridge hierarchy gaps and create an inclusive, psychologically safe global workplace.  
Keep an eye on your inbox—you won’t want to miss it! 
🔜
 
Stay tuned for Part 2!
 
 
Bye for now, 
Luiza

subject: 📩 5 Strategies to Write Emails that Resonate Across Cultures 🌎
body:
Enhance your cross-cultural communication with these essential email strategies. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Tamara!
 
👋
 Remember that email miscommunication we talked about?
 
In my last email, we explored how cultural differences can cause misunderstandings, delays, and even disengagement in the workplace.  
When emails don’t land as intended, they can erode trust, slow down productivity, and create unnecessary conflict. 
But the good news? 
You can fix this—starting today!
 
🙌
 
 
Here are 
five powerful strategies
 to help you write emails that connect, not confuse: 
1️⃣ 
Adapt Your Tone & Structure to Cultural Preferences
Some cultures (e.g., the U.S., Germany, the Netherlands) prefer 
direct and concise
 emails, while others (e.g., Japan, India, Saudi Arabia) value 
context and relationship-building
 before getting to the point. It is very important to research your audience! For example, for high-context cultures, start with a friendly introduction. For low-context cultures, lead with the key message. 
 
2️⃣ 
Choose Words That Cross Borders Effectively
In other words, avoid slang, idioms, and humor (e.g., “Let’s hit the ground running” might confuse non-native speakers). Aim for using 
clear and neutral language
 that translates well globally. For example, instead of "ASAP," try "by [specific date & time zone]." 
 
3️⃣ 
Format for Clarity & Easy Reading
Keep sentences short and use 
bullet points
 for key details. You should also consider time zones when setting deadlines. For example: "Please submit by 5 PM EST / 10 PM GMT." Another strategy would be to spell out dates. Write 
15 March 2024
, not 03/15/24, which can be misinterpreted!
 
4️⃣ 
Be Mindful of Hierarchy & Formality
Some cultures (e.g., China, France, Mexico, Brazil) expect 
titles and formality
 in emails, while others (e.g., the U.S., Australia, Sweden) are more casual. When in doubt, 
err on the side of formality
 (e.g., “Dear Mr. Chen” instead of “Hey Chen!”). 
 
5️⃣ 
Always Include a Clear Call to Action (CTA)
Different cultures respond differently to urgency. Instead of a demanding "I need this by tomorrow," try, 
Could you provide this by [specific date]? Let me know if you need more time
. 
Also,
 d
epending on the recipient’s cultural orientation, it might be appropriate to summarize the next steps at the end of your email so there’s no confusion. 
 
💡
 Ready to Elevate Your Workplace Communication? Let’s Talk!
 
Mastering cross-cultural communication isn’t just about writing better emails—it’s about 
building trust, fostering inclusion, and creating a workplace where everyone feels valued.
 
📅
 
Schedule a complimentary strategy call with me today
 and let’s explore how your organization can enhance your global communication strategies. 
 
👉
 
📅
 
Book your complimentary strategy call here.
 
Here’s to hoping your emails bring teams 
together
, not apart! 
🌏
 
Bye for now!
Luiza
___________________________________

body:

Hello Tamara!
🛑
 Picture this:
You sent an email to your global team expecting a quick reply. Instead, there’s radio silence. When responses do trickle in, they seem hesitant or even tense. You wonder—did I say something wrong? 
 
🤔
 The Experience:
The truth is that a simple email meant to be efficient can be perceived very differently depending on cultural norms. In some cultures, short and direct emails signal professionalism and clarity. In others, they may come across as cold or even rude.  
For example, a one-line email saying 
"Please send the report by Friday"
 might be perfectly acceptable when sent to a U.S. colleague but could feel abrupt and dismissive to colleagues in Japan or India, where a more relationship-focused approach is expected. 
These subtle differences can create misunderstandings, hesitation in responding, and even disengagement among your culturally diverse workforce. 
🌎💬
 
 
⚠️ 
The Problem:
Cultural differences in email communication are often overlooked, yet they can lead to serious workplace challenges, including: 
🚨
 
Misunderstandings and tension
—A straightforward request in one culture might feel abrupt or disrespectful in another.
📉
 
Decreased collaboration and engagement
—Employees are hesitant to respond due to fear of misinterpretation.
⏳
 
Delays and inefficiencies
—Multiple back-and-forth emails just to clarify a simple message.
💼
 
Lost business opportunities
—International partners may disengage if they perceive your communication as culturally insensitive. 
 
💡
 The Future You’re Waiting For:
Imagine a workplace where every email strengthens relationships rather than creating unintentional barriers. Where employees feel heard, valued, and confident in their communications—no matter their cultural background. 
A future where:
✅
 Messages are clear, culturally considerate, and well-received.
✅
 Global teams collaborate seamlessly, without misunderstandings.
✅
 Leaders foster an inclusive, high-trust environment through intentional communication. 
 
🎤
  What’s Next:
In my next email, I’ll share specific strategies you can implement 
right away
 to ensure your emails resonate across cultures—leading to better collaboration, higher engagement, and a more inclusive workplace. Stay tuned! 
📩
 
Let’s build workplaces where 
every email is a bridge—not a barrier.
 
 
Bye for now, 
Luiza

Hello Tamara!
 
🔹
 
Simple strategies to bridge time zones & cultures for better collaboration
 
 
Looping back... 
⏪
In my last email, we talked about how virtual meetings often leave out key voices due to time zone conflicts and cultural differences. This silent struggle leads to disengagement, miscommunication, and poor decision-making. 
But here’s the good news: 
You can fix this with a few simple yet powerful strategies!
 
 
🕒
 Strategy #1: Rotate Meeting Times Fairly 
💡
 
Respect work-life balance across all regions
 
Instead of expecting the same people to attend inconvenient meetings every time, 
rotate meeting times
 to share the burden equally. If someone has to join at 10 PM one week, make sure it’s someone else’s turn the next. 
✅
 
Bonus Tip:
 Use asynchronous communication (emails, recordings, and message boards) to gather input from those who can’t attend live. 
 
🗣️
 Strategy #2: Adapt to Different Communication Styles 
💡
 
Silence ≠ Agreement!
 
In some cultures, direct disagreement is seen as disrespectful, while in others, debate is encouraged. To create a safe space for all voices: 
✔️
 Allow anonymous feedback for sensitive discussions.
✔️
 Ask direct but open-ended questions like 
"How does this align with your experience?"
 instead of 
"Does everyone agree?"
✔️
 Follow up 1:1 with quieter team members to ensure they feel heard. 
 
📅
 Strategy #3: Clarify Expectations for Time & Deadlines 
💡
 
"ASAP" means different things across cultures!
 
Some cultures prioritize speed, while others value thorough deliberation. To avoid frustration: 
✔️
 Be explicit about deadlines (
e.g., “Reports due by Friday at 5 PM EST, United States”
).
✔️
 Set clear decision-making processes so that no one feels pressured or left out.
✔️
 Use collaborative tools like shared documents where people can contribute in their own time zones. 
 
🤝
 Strategy #4: Build Trust Across Cultures 
💡
 
Trust isn’t universal—it’s built differently everywhere!
 
For some, trust is based on 
credibility
 (titles, experience), for others, it’s about 
reliability
 (doing what you say) or having the opportunity to get to know each other. A successful virtual team: 
✔️
 Establishes 
team norms
 that respect both perspectives.
✔️
 Encourages small talk and informal chats to strengthen relationships.
✔️
 Uses video calls selectively—some team members may prefer writing over speaking. 
 
🚀
 Ready to Make Your Virtual Meetings More Inclusive? 
By making small but intentional changes, you can 
boost engagement, collaboration, and retention
 across your global workforce. 
 
📆
 Let’s chat!
 I’d love to help your team create virtual meetings that work for 
everyone
. Schedule a complimentary call with me today to discuss how to bring these strategies to life in your organization. 
 
👉
 
Schedule your free consultation here!
 
Because when everyone feels valued and heard, 
your entire organization wins.
 
🌟
 
Bye for now, 
Luiza

Hello Tamara!
 
🔹
 
How misaligned expectations are costing your team productivity & engagement
 
 
🛑
 Picture this:
It’s 7:00 AM for Maya in New York, midnight for Carlos in Sydney, and midday for Priya in Mumbai. They’re all logging into the same virtual meeting—cameras on, coffee (or tea) in hand. The agenda is set, but something feels 
off
. 
 
🤔
 The Experience:
🔹
 Maya notices that Carlos is unusually quiet, but assumes he has nothing to add.
🔹
 Priya, used to hierarchical decision-making, hesitates to challenge her senior colleague’s idea.
🔹
 Meanwhile, Carlos, exhausted from yet another late-night meeting, wonders why no one values his work-life balance. 
By the time the meeting ends, there’s a false sense of agreement. But in reality, misunderstandings, cultural differences, and time zone fatigue are eroding trust, engagement, and productivity. 
 
⚠️ 
The Problem:
❌
 Critical voices are being left out due to cultural communication norms.
❌
 Employees are disengaging from meetings that don’t accommodate their time zones.
❌
 Decisions are being made with incomplete input, leading to inefficiency and costly mistakes. 
This isn't just a scheduling inconvenience—it’s a 
barrier to inclusion
 that’s quietly affecting retention, innovation, and collaboration. 
 
💡
 The Future You’re Waiting For:
Imagine a workplace where…
✅
 Every employee, regardless of location or cultural background, feels valued and heard.
✅
 Meetings are structured to respect different communication styles and time zones.
✅
 Your global team collaborates effortlessly, leading to stronger, more inclusive decisions. 
 
🎤
  What’s Next:
Stay tuned for my next email, where I’ll share 
actionable strategies
 to transform your virtual meetings into inclusive, high-impact spaces. 
Because when we break these hidden barriers, we unlock 
true global collaboration.
 
🌎✨
 
 
Bye for now, 
Luiza
