subject: The Power of Us: Building Unified, Collective Movements
body:
First and foremost, Happy Black History Month. We have highlighted some new learning resources below for you to check out to support your ongoing...
 
 
 
First and foremost, Happy Black History Month. We have highlighted some new learning resources below for you to check out to support your ongoing journey. 
Throughout history, social change and civil rights movements have been rooted in shared purpose, collective action and people taking care of one another. From the 
U.S. Civil Rights movement to democratic struggles like Serbia, Chile, and Kenya
, coordinated efforts by citizens were successful because people came together with a unified vision, a commitment to peaceful action, and a willingness to leverage their individual social capital to speak truth to power. 
The last two weeks have been chaotic, with news dropping hourly that sends us reeling. We’ve seen friends and colleagues lose their jobs, seen whole departments dedicated to environmental justice and supporting diversity, equity and inclusion wiped out. It’s disheartening and demoralizing. It’s intended to be. 
That’s the playbook.
To my dear colleagues who have been directly impacted, remember this. The closing of an office does not wipe away the lives you changed with the thousands of thoughtful conversations you facilitated. The “lightbulb” moments you helped people have. The new ideas people took home to their loved ones and shared. The moments of deep, meaningful connection people experienced across their cultural and ideological differences. 
What you do matters and it ripples out.
  
You are water. So let’s flow. What comes next? We stay focused. We coalesce and share information and ideas and support each other. Yes, there is urgency.  It’s also important to take care of ourselves and one another and not fall prey to the “sky is falling” mentality. 
DEI will ultimately continue because it creates healthy, high performing organizations. 
 
The resources we share in this newsletter all offer different perspectives and examples of people working to challenge systems of oppression and doing it through collective action, community organizing, and speaking truth to power. 
Maria Morukian
Founder and Chief Executive Officer
MSM Global Consulting
MSM GLOBAL UPDATES
 
Maria Morukian Featured at the Global HR Forum in Seoul
Back in November, Maria Morukian represented MSM Global Consulting at the prestigious Global HR Forum 2024 in Seoul, South Korea. Presenting to an audience of global leaders and HR professionals, Maria led a session titled "DEIB: Tapping into the Power of Thriving Organizations." The session explored the essential role of diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging (DEIB) in fostering creativity, innovation, and sustained organizational success. Attendees gained actionable insights into building inclusive workplaces that empower employees and drive results. 
You can watch Maria Morukian's presentation on YouTube at the following link between minutes
 4:38 to 24:31
. 
Culture Stew
Have you reviewed the Culture Stew Podcast yet? We’d love for you to leave a review—your feedback helps us reach more listeners!
If you haven’t listened to our last two podcasts here they are!  
Revisit This Podcast: "Die Standing with Elmer Dixon"
In honor of Black History Month, revisit this powerful Culture Stew episode featuring Elmer Dixon, co-founder of the Seattle Chapter of the Black Panther Party. Elmer shares his journey from activism in the 1960s to his current role as a global diversity consultant. This episode provides invaluable insights into the ongoing fight for racial equity and the importance of collective action in creating systemic change.
Don’t miss this inspiring conversation: 
Listen here
Transforming Reproductive Justice: Advocating for Incarcerated Women with Dr. Carolyn Sufrin
In our latest Culture Stew episode, host Maria Morukian engages in a compelling conversation with Dr. Carolyn Sufrin, a medical anthropologist and obstetrician/gynecologist dedicated to advocating for the reproductive health and rights of incarcerated women. Dr. Sufrin shares her transformative journey from witnessing the harsh realities of childbirth in custody to leading pivotal research and policy initiatives aimed at systemic reform. This episode sheds light on the intersection of reproductive justice, incarceration, and systemic inequities, emphasizing the urgent need for compassionate healthcare and policy change.
Listen to the full episode here: 
Transforming Reproductive Justice: Advocating for Incarcerated Women with Dr. Carolyn Sufrin
Have you reviewed the Culture Stew Podcast yet? Please do! A short five star review can help get the podcast out to more viewers! 
MSM GLOBAL GALLERY
Here you can find curated content of current DEI issues and events for your further exploration.
 
Global Mentorship Initiative
Building meaningful connections can change lives, and the Global Mentorship Initiative (GMI) is doing just that. GMI pairs experienced professionals with young graduates worldwide, offering career guidance and mentorship to help bridge professional gaps. This global program emphasizes the power of mentorship to foster mutual growth, create opportunities, and build a stronger, more connected workforce. Discover how you can be part of this impactful network.
Learn more: 
Global Mentorship Initiative
Black History Month in the UK: A Global Perspective
While Black History Month originated in the U.S., its celebration has grown worldwide, taking on unique significance in different regions. In the UK, Black History Month emphasizes the contributions of Black Britons to culture, politics, and society. This global perspective offers lessons in solidarity, shared histories, and the ongoing fight for equity. Explore how the UK’s approach can inspire deeper connections across borders.
Learn more: 
Black History Month UK
IDEAS League 
We need community now more than ever in this time of political turmoil. IDEAS Generation is a community of changemakers that is launching the IDEAS League, a year-long community of practice to navigate the uncertainty through dynamic workshops, facilitated strategy sessions, and more. All who are passionate about social change are welcome to join in this necessary and important work! Check out our website for more information:

CONTENT FOR YOUR DOWN TIME
Here are some recommended articles and books for your down time.
 
Lies About Black People: How to Combat Racist Stereotypes and Why it Matters
 by Dr. Omekongo Dibinga
 is a timely and indispensable guide for those seeking to navigate the complexities of racial bias and inequality. Dr. Dibinga, a seasoned diversity and inclusion expert, skillfully dismantles harmful stereotypes about the Black community through a combination of personal anecdotes, historical inquiry, and analysis of contemporary events. The book not only exposes pervasive lies, such as the criminalization of Black individuals, but also provides readers with practical tools for self-reflection and confronting their own biases. With a focus on re-education and the importance of dismantling harmful narratives, Dr. Dibinga’s work is an invaluable resource for anyone committed to fostering understanding, taking action, and contributing to the ongoing fight for racial equality in our society.
 
Afrocentric Voices in Classical Music
Classical music is often viewed through a Eurocentric lens, but Black composers and performers have significantly shaped its history. Afrocentric Voices in Classical Music shines a light on these contributions, celebrating the rich legacy of Black artists in this genre. Explore this resource to discover trailblazing musicians whose work transcends borders and fosters a deeper connection to global cultural diversity.
Learn more: 
Afrocentric Voices
Chevalier
“Son of an African slave and a French farmer, Joseph Bologne, Chevalier de Saint-Georges, achieves an unthinkable position in society as a famous violinist, composer and fencer, in addition to experiencing an ill-fated love affair.”

Judge pauses federal worker buyout offer deadline 
 
Two days after unions representing more than 800,000 federal workers asked the court to halt the Trump administration’s buyout program, a federal judge in Massachusetts paused the Thursday deadline.
